children.subject: But looking at the description from the l&s website wouldn't it be allowed?

It seems like there are two questions you might be asking here.

If your question is, "will I be allowed to enroll in this class again", see Nicole's answer above. (In the past, students have been allowed to reenroll in a class they have already taken (hence why the L&S website addresses this possibility), but it remains to be seen if this will still be allowed in the future.)

If your question is: "will I be able to use my grade in this class for the CS minor or to satisfy any other requirements", the answer is no: the fact that you took the class again and your second grade in the class is basically ignored by everyone. Since all requirements for the minor must be taken for a letter grade, and you got a P in 61C, you will not be able to complete the CS minor, even if you take the class again (because the second grade doesn't count).

history.content:
The new enrollment system has been advertised as enforcing the university policy that discourages students from enrolling in courses that they've received a passing grade in. This means that although you theoretically course P the course and re-enroll for a letter grade in past semesters, doing so this semester means you take the risk that this will be enforced and functional when you try to re-enroll in the course. You may? be able to petition the department to manually add the course.
Unfortunately there's a lot of uncertainty at this time and I can't give you a "yes" or "no" answer. It's a cost-benefit analysis you'll have to make. Personally, I would stay letter graded.

That's all I know,
Nicole
http://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades

I'm pursuing a CS minor. Would I be allowed to P/NP it this semester, receive a P in the course, and still be able to retake the course in the future for a letter grade? According to the L&S website, this is allowed:

  • If you repeat a course in which you received a passing grade (other than a D, F, NP, or U), the course will count as part of your course schedule for the semester and the grade you earn will be listed on your transcript.
  • However, the grade will not be included in your GPA, and the course units will not count toward graduation unless the course description in the Berkeley Academic Guide states "course may be repeated for credit."
history.subject: P/NP 61C
